Description of service: An official copy of a register or title plan represents a true record of entries in the register and extent of the registered title at a specific date and time. It is admissible as evidence in court proceedings as if it were the original.
Notes on costs: Applications can be received via different channels, requiring different processes and may contain multiple transactions. The published cost per transaction is therefore an average cost, including apportioned overheads, based on Land Registry’s 2011/12 published accounts.

Department: Department for Business, Innovation and Skills
Name of service: Land Registry: searches for title numbers
Description of service: The purpose of a search of the index map is to find out whether or not land is registered and, if so, to obtain the title number. Any person may apply for an official search of the index map.
Notes on costs: Applications can be received via different channels, requiring different processes and may contain multiple transactions. The published cost per transaction is therefore an average cost, including apportioned overheads, based on Land Registry’s 2011/12 published accounts.

Department: Department for Business, Innovation and Skills
Name of service: Land Registry: searches of whole register
Description of service:
A person who wishes to protect a transaction for value, such as purchase, lease or charge, may make an official search of whole with priority against either the whole or part of a registered title or pending first registration.
The effect of the official search with priority is to “freeze” the title to allow the application to be lodged. This protected application takes priority over other applications lodged within the priority period.
Notes on costs: Applications can be received via different channels, requiring different processes and may contain multiple transactions. The published cost per transaction is therefore an average cost, including apportioned overheads, based on Land Registry’s 2011/12 published accounts.

Department: Department of Health
Description of service: Applications for European Health Insurance Cards. The EHIC replaced the E111 in 2006. An EHIC lets patients get state healthcare in Europe at a reduced cost or sometimes free.
Notes on costs:
Average cost per transaction includes:
- staff - estimated cost of salaries, pensions and National Insurance contributions for staff directly involved in the process
- overheads - includes all the related administrative expenditure including EHIC management, information technology maintenance and estates; capital expenditure, including IT development costs and depreciation, are excluded
- printing and distribution - includes internal printing costs, cost of stationery, cards, card personalisation, printing of carrier letters, and sorting of mail

Costs relating to the production, distribution and promotion of EHIC application forms and the processing of medical expenses claims are excluded. The Department for Work and Pensions is responsible for these costs.
Other notes:
Figures have been calculated based on number of applications processed rather than on the number of cards issued. More than one card may be issued per application. An EHIC is valid for five years.
EHIC applications can be made online, by post or by telephone, but the following applicants can only apply by post:

1) Dependants of a citizen working in the UK, who live in an EU member state
2) Pensioners or persons who are in receipt of long-term benefit from the UK who live in an EU member state
3) Non- European Economic Area (EEA) nationals.

Description of service: Pregnant women and those who have had a baby in the last 12 months can apply for a maternity exemption (MATEX) certificate. The certificate can entitle them to free NHS prescriptions and NHS dental treatment.
Notes on costs:
Average cost per transaction includes:
- postage - estimate of cost incurred for use of a postal service; this figure does not include the cost of stationery
- staff - estimated cost of salaries, pensions and National Insurance contributions for staff directly involved in the process
- overheads - includes all related administrative expenditure including management, information technology maintenance and estates; capital expenditure, including IT development costs and depreciation, are excluded
- printing and distribution - includes internal printing costs, cost of stationery, cards, card personalisation, printing of carrier letters, and sorting of mail
Other notes:
The NHS Business Services Authority administers Maternity Exemption Certificates for England only.
The MATEX certificate provides entitlement to free NHS prescriptions. However, a woman who is pregnant or has had a baby in the last 12 months is entitled to free NHS dental treatment without a valid certificate. For NHS dental treatment, the certificate is used as a means of proof of entitlement.

Department: Department of Health
Description of service: People with certain medical conditions can get free NHS prescriptions if they hold a valid medical exemption (MEDEX) certificate.
Notes on costs:
Average cost per transaction includes:
- postage - estimate of cost incurred for use of a postal service; this figure does not include the cost of stationery
- staff - estimated cost of salaries, pensions and National Insurance contributions for staff directly involved in the process
- overheads - includes all related administrative expenditure including management, information technology maintenance and estates; capital expenditure, including IT development costs and depreciation, are excluded
- printing and distribution - includes internal printing costs, cost of stationery, cards, card personalisation, printing of carrier letters, and sorting of mail
Other notes:
The NHS Business Services Authority administers MEDEX certificates for England only.
The MEDEX certificate can be used by patients until it expires even if the patient's medical condition improves. After 5 years, a new application may be made if the patient still suffers from the qualifying medical conditions.
A holder of a valid medical exemption is entitled to free NHS prescriptions for all prescriptions and not just those relating to their medical condition.
